text: ip got an superficial cut on his left thumb while cutting the excess tubular brace  on 13 april, 2019 at about 2237hrs ip was carrying out cutting activity of tubular bracing using hilti battery saw. due to the awkward position the ip operated the power tool, the blade of the saw got stuck and deformed. ip then tried to free the blade by dislodging the power tool from the excess tubular brace. unfortunately, as he operated the power tool, his left thumb got pinched by the moving part (lock blade mechanism) causing the ip to suffer a superficial cut. at about 2240hrs ip immediately reported to hsse on duty. at 2241hrs was brought to the medic and treated as first aid treatment. •	hsse time out was held to discuss event and learnings from event (done – 14 apr 2019 at ap tbt area)•	re-enforce constant situational awareness prior to and during jobs (tbt’s/jha) •	ensure all mitigations outlined in permit to work are strictly adhered to •	perform hsse focus audits on power tools.•	develop specific inspection checklist for power tools.•	permit to work audit on all activities by supervisors needs to be conducted.

welder’s helper stepped up into the back of a pickup truck bed and his right knee buckled, causing him to fall backwards to the ground. at approximately 5:30 pm, thursday, november 7, 2019, a welder’s helper was finishing work in the fab area.  he was loading tools onto the welder’s rig truck. it was clear and overcast.  weather was not an issue.the welder’s helper was finishing up putting the tools away.  he had one more item to put away.  he opened the tailgate and placed the tools on it.  he stated he stepped up onto a step attached to the tow hitch of the truck with his right leg.  he then stepped onto the tailgate with his left foot.  he was stepping up onto the tailgate with his right leg when his right knee “popped” and he felt pain and fell backwards off the tailgate.  after the fall, site management got a paramedic to evaluate the employee.  the paramedic stated he was unsure of unseen damage to the knee and recommended further diagnostic testing.  he was transported by a co-worker to a clinic in carlsbad, nm.  x-rays were negative and he was given a release to return to work. after the fall, site management got a paramedic to evaluate the employee.  the paramedic stated he was unsure of unseen damage to the knee and recommended further diagnostic testing.  he was transported by a co-worker to a clinic in carlsbad, nm.  x-rays were negative and he was given a release to return to work.

category: hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: ip was opening a sliding door and jammed his hand between the door handle and wall. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30957summaryip works as a maintenance rigger on bp magnus and has for several years. the position is embedded to bp and removed from any wg project work that may take place on the platform. at the time of incident though, there were a few contract 'labour supply' persons on board, but no direct wg offshore supervision. all personnel on the bp upstream contract offshoreare currently under consultation.at the date and time stated, ip along with one other, weretransporting a 2t valve on a pallet truck on bp magnus.the item being moved was large and awkward. on arriving at the module 6 south door (which slides right to left from the external side),the teamstoppedto open it and manoeuvre the pallet to fit the door entrance.prior to opening, persons are required to contact the control room to request access, given it enters into the tr. the dooris alarge blast door which takes considerable effort from one person to open. it slides into the blast wall nearby from the internal side, and noticeably, has nomeans of door stop, instead stopping when the handle clashes with the wall frame. this being obvious by the lack of paint on the frame.at this juncture, the party were joined by a third person (sparrows rigger). this person offered assistance with the task being carried out and was subsequently taken through the permit, tbt, drr processand signed having been made aware of the task and associated hazards/risks.asip attempted toslide the door open himself, he got to the half way point before reaching his right hand inside thus straddling the door in order to grab the internal handle. at this point, ip wasassisted by the mentionedthird party. with added excursion of 2 people, this meant the door slid open with more ease and quicker. it therefore resultedin ip's right thumb striking the internal wall frame when trapped between that and the handle (see site pictures to appreciate door set up).on feeling pain to his hand, ip immediately visited the medic where he was assessed and it was noted that his right hand had swollen. he received adressing and paracetamol as treatment and was stood down for the remainder of his shift. .on realising the swelling hadn't gone down, ip was medevac'd on the next available flight on monday 1st august. he was met by the contract team and conveyed to a&e where it was conformed that his thumb was fractured.he had a cast put on his thumb and due to the type of fracture was advised the injury would be reviewed in 6 weeks at ari. ip was conveyed home and his welfare reviewed periodically. there is no restricted duties suitable for ip on the contract at this time.points highlighted from bp investigationdoor design – ‘door is an original unmodified design with no stop’ reporting behaviour – ‘the entire work party and members of the management team, when questioned about the door handle, were aware of the potential for hand trap injuries with said handle, but this door had not been modified to eliminate the hazard’.human factors – the investigation team highlighted the timing around ip being given his notice period whilst offshore 4 days into his trip. see action associated with conversation between janette fullerton-draper, wg hse manager and suzanne turnbull, bp hse contracts advisor and attached timeline document.findings – 1). toleration of known defect (no stop) through poor reporting behaviour.2). door requires a physical stop to eliminate hazard. 3). door is stiff and requires to be oiled. 4). door signage requires re-stencil (exterior). migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19  a wood employee was reported to wood supervision that they began to experience cov19 s/s on 1/10/2022.  the wood employee scheduled a covid 19 test on 1/111/2022, and was informed on 1/11/2022 the employee is positive for cov19. the employee was last on site on 1/9/2022. contact tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.  employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19 			 a wood employee received a positive covid-19 test result on 07/22/2020.  the wood employee was not experiencing symptoms and scheduled a covid 19 test which was a positive result.  contact tracing has been completed. the employee self quarantined. management and hsse conducted contact tracing for the work site.  there is no other impact to the site or wood employees.

tick bite ip reports sitting in truck on job site found tick on abdomen above pant line. tick was a small tick that was approximately the size of a ball point pen. there were two sites. work care contacted, advised to take antihistamines or topical hydro cortisone for itching and to keep the area cleaned with antibacterial soap.

observed crane loading out 15 bbl cutting box of high bs&w oil onto supply boat. the lid was not tight enough and oil (1 pint or less) spilled out onto boat deck and other equipment. due to this incident being a third party we re-classified to report migrated from legacy cairs incident #31146observed crane loading out 15 bbl cutting box of high bs&w oil onto supply boat. the lid was not tight enoughand oil spilled out onto boat deck and other equipment. while lifting the cutting box, it bumped another cutting box on the boat causing the corner of the hatch to become open and caused a leak. this was immediately corrected.due to this incident being a third party we re-classified to report only 8/25/16. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee reaches up to grab a box, not seeing the large phone on top of the box. the phone drops striking the employee in the head.  basic first aid. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30291employee was assisting in removing boxes out a closet shelve, when they reached up to grab the next box. an old large phone that was laying on top, it fell, striking the employee in the head. the employee notified supervision and axiom. basic first aid was recommended. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

while off-loading torque tubes, some tubes rolled off flat-bed trailer. on wednesday september 23 at approximately 2:00pm, employees were off-loading torque tubes from a flat bed trailer. during the off-loading, some tubes rolled of trailer. there were no injuries and no damage to the tubes. incident rated as c1 because the road was blocked, spotters in a safe location, and low potential for worse outcome.  the crew was brought together for a stand down and went over the 5 why's. moving forward, a plan was created to prevent this from happening again. they will make sure the loose bundles are strapped together before loading and unloading.

the pushbar on the boom extension was bent as a result of double blocking of the lifting hook.  at the morning prestart meeting the crane crew were told to be available for lifting and landing of materials by who ever should require their assistance. there first call was to attend at area 2181 and to pick and carry a cage from the 2181 laydown area and land it in the 2182 concrete pad.  the operator and dogman rigged the cage and then transported it to the eastern boundary of the concrete pad near the windrow. the dogman positioned himself where the cage was to be landed and the operator commenced to telescope out the load. once the boom was fully extended at 13.9m the dogman informed the crane operator the load was about 500mm short of the target. it was then agreed to land the load where it was, retract the boom and reposition so they could set the manual extension and then pick up and land the load the extra 500mm to the correct position.                                                                                                                                          the crane operator was attempting to set the manual extension for the boom and during the process he has failed to feed adequate amount of winch rope to the fall block whilst retracting the boom. this action caused the fall block to rise hard up against the head of the boom resulting in double blocking.       the operator stopped the crane, set the brake and informed his supervisor. investigation initiated.

coffee-maker "sparking" client pa emailed fm service centre to say that "the coffee-maker on the counter-top was sparking this morning.  your urgent attention is required to remove and make safe.i had thought it was leaking for a while, but wasn’t sure about that.  today, it was definitely leaking and sparked fire." pa requested fm to remove item.
wood employee tested positive to covid-19 wood employee underwent swab which resulted positive covid-19 protocoll has been always respected. no more action needed.

one (1) wood has tested positive for covid-19 personnel felt mild symptoms of covid-19 after which he administered a test on himself which resulted in a positive result personnel will self isolate at home and ministry of health will guide further. disinfection will be carried out to the affected area. covid-19 case reported to statutory board.

category: general illness or health issue, electric shock or issue
text: ee suffered personal medical issue. while working inside an electrical panel (tb-15) de-terminating cables, employee suffered a medical issue of a personal nature. the employee was sitting on his knees while working inside the panel. a coworker noticed the employee was in distress and pulled him away from the panel and laid him back to prevent further injury. there were live 120v circuits inside the panel however they had been guarded to prevent access prior to the task commencing and all employees had been notified that the circuits were live but guarded from contact. all exposed circuits inside the panel had been verified that they were de-energized prior to beginning the task. amec foster wheeler safety department was contacted and responded along with lg&e emergency response team.employee was transported to local hospital by lg&e ambulance for further evaluation and escorted by amec foster wheeler safety department.employee was released with no restrictions.

on 11/13/2018 a wood employee stated he was attempting to pick up a spool piece and felt discomfort in arm. employee was taken to off site clinic for evaluation and was released back to work with first aid treatment. migrated from legacy cairs incident #40089an employee was picking through piping in the laydown area and stated that he thought the weight of the piece needed "was not very heavy", actual weight of spool piece was approximately (researching amount now). employee stated that when he picked up spool piece he felt discomfort in his arm. the employee did not report the incident to supervision or hsse at the time of the incident on 11/13/2018. the employee came into work this morning (11/14/2018) and reported that he had discomfort to his arm. the employee was taken to the off site clinic for evaluation and was released back to work with first aid treatment. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

hb-21-2016 loss of containment of nitrogen and water from inlet heater b migrated from legacy cairs incident #31793on arriving at the scene of the incident the operations technicians noted that there was an intermittent release of water and nitrogen from the flange joint of the shell end of the inlet heater. the released water was noted to strike the 1st stage separator adjacent to the inlet heater then fall in to the bunded area beneath the separator; all water was contained within the bunded area. after approximately 10-15 minutes the pressure within the inlet heater had fallen and the release of water ceased. finding/s:1. after referring to riddor schedule 2 part 6 section 77. the unintentional or uncontrolled release or escape of any substance (other than petroleum hydrocarbon) on or from an offshore installation which could cause a  significant risk of personal injury to any person. at the time of the incident a wind direction of 020° at 23knts was noted. due to the wind direction and  speed any release of nitrogen would have been blown over the port side of the vessel away from the process deck where personnel were working. at the time of the incident no work was being under taken on the port side of the installation2. during gas lift activities pressures were cycling between 8 and 11 bar. the inlet heater vessel has a high, high alarm trip of 14 bar.3. directly above the area of the incident a gas head is located, at no time did the gas head go in to alarm or any adjacent gas heads. 4. all water released was contained within the bunded area within the process area.5. an entry in to the weeps and seeps register had been added on the 08/11/2015 inlet heater b on process deck, and work order 510350 raised, this work order was completed on 15/06/16 it was noted at the time “during the recent scale squeeze we used this opportunity to check/reset the end cap bolt settings. leak has not been apparent since remedial work was completed (20/5/16). ops have monitored for leaks daily ( as per weeps and  seeps register), until 15/6/16 no issues to report. this has now been removed from weeps and seeps register”. on the 28/08/16 daily checks were resumed.6. on inspection of the flange gasket the gasket had split in to a number of pieces. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

massy wood employee stepped onto a corroded grating which was not supported on all sides. the grating shifted under his weight, causing the employee to twist his ankle. migrated from legacy cairs incident #40211on tuesday 27th november 2018 at approximately 2:40 pm, whilst routing hoses for the fabricmaintenance activities in the well bay area of the cellar deck, a massy wood employee stepped ontoa grating which was not supported on all sides due to part of it being corroded. the grating shiftedunder his weight, causing the employee to twist his ankle.the employee immediately reported the incident to his supervisor and was taken to the platformmedic. the medic reviewed the employee and he was treated for slight swelling and light pain, via anice pack and pain medication, respectively. he was also administered a topical pain medication.the employee was cleared fit for duty and was resting comfortably at the end of his shiftthe incident is currently reported late due to limitations experienced with reporting this incident. thisrequired cairs administrator to insert new area: client/contract (shell fms). migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  an employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation since january 18th. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed.

truck during reversing collided with ykk operated vehicle. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31885during maneuvering on fuel station forecourt, a truck reversed in to a ykk operated vehicle. the ykk vehicle was stationary at the time of impact and signalised with the horn. there were no injuriesjust rear door of pickup was dented. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

pipe fitter felt discomfort to the lower back when installing cladding on pipework pipe fitter felt discomfort to the lower back when installing cladding on pipework  hse notified. ip was assessed at site medical centre where over the counter pain relief was administered. ip returned to work with no restriction.

rented vehicle stole on august 24 at around 6:00 am, an employee went to look for rented vehicle by wood, parked outside his residence to go to the client's premises and realized that it was stolen. so he reports the event to the police department and notifies the rental company and the insurance company. no injuries nor contact with the wood employee whatsoever. report to the police department and notifies the rental company and the insurance company

category: ppe non-compliance, site compliance or practice issue
text: two members of a four man work party were inside a hard barrier area with no harness worn.  work stopped and area made safe the bp plt was walking past the work area located on well a-01 when he noticed two members of a work party inside a hard barrier area and two of the individuals were were not wearing a harness as fall protection. the activity was stopped until a gap in the grating had been covered up using two scaffold boards. the work was completed during that shift the work area was made safe and the work was completed.

burst water pipe resulted in damage to toilet ceiling and server room at approximately 08.30am on the morning of the 26th november 2020 it was reported that there was a burst water pipe connected to the hand wash basins in the 5th floor toilet area in the psns office. this resulted in water ingress to the it server room and toilet area in the 4th floor, both of which are directly underneath and adjacent to the area of the leak on the 5th floor causing water ingress to both areas which resulted in the plasterboard ceiling in the toilet area on the 4th floor became saturated with water thus becoming loose from its fixings and partly dislodged. no personnel were in both of these areas at this this time.  based on receipt of this information the server room was isolated and de-energised. an hse risk assessment was carried out with a toolbox talk with the it team and building maintenance team prior to commencing any assessment of the affected areas. after an hse inspection both areas were deemed safe to enter. 2 x server units were observed to have been affected by this leak. after drying off some small areas of surface water on server external casings, the it team removed  various drawers/racks to be assessed in more detail for any damage. the drawers were removed from the actual service room and assessed. the toilet area was barriered off with the damaged pipe isolated and replaced.

ip went over on right ankle whilst accessing the tank compound  ip was walking into the tank compound when he went over on his right ankle, he felt immediate pain but continued with his work, the ip did not report the incident until the next day 4th december at 13:30 hrs  hsse advisor visited the ip on site with the operations manager, the ip gave a brief account of what happened, the hsse advisor insisted the ip visited the stanlow medical facility. the ip visited the medical centre and was examined by a site nurse and paramedic. no treatment was given ip told to apply heat when required to ease swelling. the ip is limping operations manager made the decision to restrict duties and place the ip in the stores with limited walking

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: employee received minor contusion to right knee when they slipped down step exiting the driver’s side of water truck. employee received minor contusion to right knee when they slipped down step exiting the driver’s side of water truck. employee reported incident to supervisor. employee was taken to on-site pa where they were evaluated, treated and released back to work without restrictions.

employee received a burn to his left palm after touching truck bed mounted air compressor muffler.   employee and coworker were utilizing the truck air compressor to run an impact wrench for change a tire. upon completion of the tire change the ip was attempting to drain the air compressor and placed his left hand on the air compressor exhaust manifold burning his palm.  actual: b1 rating due to first aid measures being applied to the burn. potential: b2 rating due to potential need of medical treatment for the injury.  employee was evaluated at xtreme md in kenedy, tx and released to full duty with first aid measures for the burn.

at approximately 13:00 hours- client operations observed a bolt bag on fire resulting in damage to near by electrical cable. at approximately 13:00 hours- client operations observed a bolt bag on fire resulting in damage to near by electrical cable. work stopped, area secured and investigation commenced.all hot work in area suspended till further investigation completed.

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  an employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation since october 1st. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. this is the fifth positive result for the 5th  of october.

person subcontracted to amec through the elxp passed maximum days requirement offshore without risk assessment as per client procedure. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30374summaryas part of changes to the bpprocedure and rota, mandatory personal risk assessment changed from 21 to 28 days for suitability of continuation of workoffshore. said risk assessments should be carried out by an appropriate supervisor and signed off by the platform oim.during early april, arrangements were made for wgis persons to be recruited through the wgpsn contract in order to conduct work as part of the elxp through amec. at that time said arrangements included date parameters up to and including 4th may (3 week trip) with the guys falling under the supervision of amec.on 3rd may 2016, joe doherty, amec construction superintendent,requested through direct contact with paul guntrip wgis senior operationa manager, thatone of thewgisguys extend their trip to 30 days to assist with work scope coverage. this was agreed by those parties and accommodated.on 10th may 2016, it was identified that said individual had worked 29 straight days without elxp logistics identifying same meaning a risk assessment wasn't in place to manage his suitability to continue working. the individual was immediately stood down and subsequently returned onshore as part of hisagreed demob arrangements.update - actions addressed with logistics now conducting a daily check to monitor mungo/etappob movementin respect of days worked. also, expectations set around communication channels through the contract by amec/wgis. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was cutting frozen cornish hen with a band saw when he amputated the tip of his left ring finger.
struck by swinging part of powered vehicle an employee's hand was crushed by a skidsteer rock bucket as it was being taken off of a pallet.
compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee's finger was partially amputated after getting caught between a wood part and work table while feeding parts into a gusset machine.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was fixing a vacuum roll on a machine. the employee's left index finger was crushed between the vacuum roll and the table. the finger was amputated.

other jump to lower level, unspecified an employee was working on the rig floor. equipment fell to the rig floor and the employee jumped off the rig onto the ground suffering a compound fracture to the right ankle.

caught between rolling powered vehicle and other object an employee was backing into an aisle with a motorized power jack when he lost balance and stepped off the jack. his right foot was then pinched between the power jack and a rack, requiring overnight hospitalization.

text: struck by dislodged flying object, particle on june 1, 2018, an employee was pressing a hydraulic shaft with a manually operated hydraulic press when a piece of metal that had not cleared the press table ejected and struck his left pinky finger, causing tendon damage that required hospitalization and stitches.

text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on an extension ladder installing a panel and caulking units. the employee fell from the ladder onto the concrete pavement below. the ladder appeared to have struck the employee as it also fell. the employee lost consciousness and was hospitalized for a head laceration requiring sutures, a concussion, and broken ribs.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee lifted a rare earth magnet from a materials hopper. he handed the magnet to a second employee.  the second employee took the magnet and began to set the magnet down on an adjacent piece of equipment.  as the second employee set the magnet down, the magnet pulled itself to the piece of equipment that he was going to place it on. his left-hand ring finger was crushed between the magnet and the equipment and had to be surgically amputated at the first knuckle.

struck by object or equipment, unspecified an employee was attempting to repair a gantry crane when stored energy caused the crane's hydraulic motor wheel to release and strike the employee, breaking the left arm and middle finger.
struck by or caught in swinging door or gate an employee's left middle fingertip was amputated after getting caught in the door.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident on may 05, 2017, an employee was operating an electric pallet jack. he was traveling with the forks behind him and was standing on the left side of the platform on the pallet jack. when he approached a staged pallet of product, he turned his pallet jack to the left and made a full circle to get under the pallet of product. as he was positioning his forks under the pallets, he hit another pallet of product. his right ankle was pinned between his pallet jack and the pallet of product, peeling off the skin and requiring surgery.

hitting, kicking, beating, shoving two employees were arguing over a method to fix an overhead garage door. employee 1 lunged at employee 2 with a box cutter. employee 2 struck employee 1 on the head with a cordless impact wrench. employee 2 was rendered unconscious and was hospitalized with a head injury.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment on 10/10/2018, around 8:30 a.m., an employee was attempting to replace a motor on a press machine when the employee was pinned between the motor and the machine frame, suffering contusions that required hospitalization.

struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee's index finger was cut by a conveyor belt. the belt was unguarded at the time.

category: hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level, unspecified while delivering mail, an employee fell and broke an arm.

category: vehicle incident general, dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was moving a rack of 25 20-foot steel channel stacks, weighing 625 pounds, on a cart. the cart got stuck on a crack on the ground and tipped over; the channels fell onto the employee's left leg and broke it.
bites and stings, unspecified an employee was bitten by a spider.

category: knife incident, foot or leg injury
text: injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was cutting a notch in a plastic battery box with a razor knife. the knife slipped off the box and cut three tendons in his left knee.

category: fall from or working at height issue, foot or leg injury
text: other fall to lower level 11 to 15 feet  an employee was installing a gutter and fell approximately 11 feet from the roof. the employee sustained a right foot fracture.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was using a band saw to cut meat. the saw amputated the tip of the employee's right middle finger.
fall on same level due to slipping  an employee slipped and fell on ice while delivering propane to a customer's home. the employee suffered a concussion and was hospitalized.

category: fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified on 8/30/2017, an employee was repairing a roof when he fell off, fracturing his heel.

fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was walking, tripped over the foot of the merchandise cart and fell. the employee was hospitalized for a fractured and dislocated shoulder.

category: vehicle incident general, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified an employee was working in the aisle stocking items when a forklift was leaving the receiving department.  the forklift hit the employee in the stock aisle and pinned them against the shelving unit. the employee sustained a broken ankle and a ruptured liver.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was removing an attachment from a skid steer. he released the locking devices of the bucket and disconnected hydraulic hoses from the machine, but the bucket did not separate completely from the machine. the employee operated the machine and raised the bucket to check if debris was preventing it from disconnecting. when he came over to check the bucket, it dropped on and broke his left foot.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury
text: struck against stationary object or equipment, unspecified an employee was installing pipes and ducts in an attic space. his elbow struck a metal frame and was injured.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was wiping the tension roller on a 6-inch slitter with a rag. the rag and the employee's right hand were pulled into the roller; the employee's fingers were crushed and degloved.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: nonroadway collision with other vehicle, unspecified an employee was operating a pallet jack when the employee backed up into another driver whose load of pallets then fell onto the employee. the employee sustained a crushed left leg and broken left femur, requiring hospitalization and surgery.

category: vehicle incident general, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified an employee was struck by a forklift, suffering a broken leg and ankle. he was hospitalized and had surgery.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was attempting to hold branches from one shrub out of the way while trimming another shrub with a gas-powered hedge trimmer. the trimmer then amputated his left little fingertip and cut his ring finger.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee cleaning up roofing material fell 7 feet off the edge of a roof.

category: fall from or working at height issue, back injury
text: other fall to lower level 21 to 25 feet  on june 1, 2017, at approximately 4:00 pm, an employee was descending from a two-story roof onto a ladder. as the employee climbed from the roof to the ladder, the ladder slid sideways, causing the employee and ladder to fall to the ground. the employee suffered a broken pelvis and two broken vertebrae.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping over self while walking, an employee tripped and fell to the floor. the employee suffered a broken elbow and was hospitalized.

fall on same level, unspecified an employee was carrying a bucket of water. the bucket fell to the floor; then the employee fell, suffering second- and third-degree burns to the arm and stomach from the water.
